column1: <!-- NOTE: Any NULL bytes in requests and responses are preserved within this output
column2: even though this strictly breaks the XML syntax. If your XML parser rejects the NULL bytes then you will need to remove or replace these bytes before parsing. Alternatively
column3: you can use the option to base64-encode requests and responses. -->

column1: TLS (or SSL) helps to protect the confidentiality and integrity of information in transit between the browser and server
column2: and to provide authentication of the server's identity. To serve this purpose
column3: the server must present an TLS certificate that is valid for the server's hostname
column4: is issued by a trusted authority and is valid for the current date. If any one of these requirements is not met
column5: TLS connections to the server will not provide the full protection for which TLS is designed.

column1: It should be noted that various attacks exist against TLS in general
column2:
and in the context of HTTPS web connections in particular. It may be possible for a determined and suitably-positioned attacker to compromise TLS connections without user detection even when a valid TLS certificate is used.

]]>

column1: The application returned a redirection response containing a "long" message body. Ordinarily
column2: this content is not displayed to the user
column3: because the browser automatically follows the redirection.

column2: redirection responses contain sensitive data. For example
column3: if the user requests a page that they are not authorized to view
column4: then an application might issue a redirection to a different page
column5: but also include the contents of the prohibited page.

column1:
You should review the contents of the response to determine whether it contains anything sensitive.

]]>
In cases where the application handles requests for unauthorized content by redirecting to a different URL
column2: the application should ensure that no sensitive content is included within the redirection response. Depending on the application and the platform
column3: this might involve checking for proper authorization earlier in the request handling logic
column4:
or using a different API to perform the redirection.

]]>

The application fails to prevent users from connecting to it over unencrypted connections. An attacker able to modify a legitimate user's network traffic could bypass the application's use of SSL/TLS encryption
column2: and use the application as a platform for attacks against its users. This attack is performed by rewriting HTTPS links as HTTP
column3: so that if a targeted user follows a link to the site from an HTTP page
column4: their browser never attempts to use an encrypted connection. The sslstrip tool automates this process.

column2: an attacker must be suitably positioned to intercept and modify the victim's network traffic.This scenario typically occurs when a client communicates with the server over an insecure connection such as public Wi-Fi
column3:
or a corporate or home network that is shared with a compromised computer. Common defenses such as switched networks are not sufficient to prevent this. An attacker situated in the user's ISP or the application's hosting infrastructure could also perform this attack. Note that an advanced adversary could potentially target any connection made over the Internet's core infrastructure.

]]>

column1: The application should instruct web browsers to only access the application using HTTPS. To do this
column2: enable HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) by adding a response header with the name 'Strict-Transport-Security' and the value 'max-age=expireTime'
column3: where expireTime is the time in seconds that browsers should remember that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS. Consider adding the 'includeSubDomains' flag if appropriate.

column1: Note that because HSTS is a "trust on first use" (TOFU) protocol
column2: a user who has never accessed the application will never have seen the HSTS header
column3: and will therefore still be vulnerable to SSL stripping attacks. To mitigate this risk
column4: you can optionally add the 'preload' flag to the HSTS header
column5:
and submit the domain for review by browser vendors.

]]>

column1: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:103.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/103.0
Source code intended to be kept server-side can sometimes end up being disclosed to users. Such code may contain sensitive information such as database passwords and secret keys
column2:
which may help malicious users formulate attacks against the application.

]]>

column1: Server-side source code is normally disclosed to clients as a result of typographical errors in scripts or because of misconfiguration
column2:
such as failing to grant executable permissions to a script or directory. Review the cause of the code disclosure and prevent it from happening.

]]>

File upload functionality is commonly associated with a number of vulnerabilities

• File path traversal
  • Persistent cross-site scripting
  • Placing of other client-executable code into the domain
  • Transmission of viruses and other malware
  • Denial of service
You should review file upload functionality to understand its purpose
column2: and establish whether uploaded content is ever returned to other application users
column3: either through their normal usage of the application or by being fed a specific link by an attacker.

column1: Some factors to consider when evaluating the security impact of this functionality include:

• Whether uploaded content can subsequently be downloaded via a URL within the application.
  • What Content-type and Content-disposition headers the application returns when the file's content is downloaded.
  • Whether it is possible to place executable HTML/JavaScript into the file
column2:
which executes when the file's contents are viewed.
  • Whether the application performs any filtering on the file extension or MIME type of the uploaded file.
  • Whether it is possible to construct a hybrid file containing both executable and non-executable content
column3: to bypass any content filters - for example
column4:
a file containing both a GIF image and a Java archive (known as a GIFAR file).
  • What location is used to store uploaded content
column5:
and whether it is possible to supply a crafted filename to escape from this location.
  • Whether archive formats such as ZIP are unpacked by the application.
  • How the application handles attempts to upload very large files

column1: File upload functionality is not straightforward to implement securely. Some recommendations to consider in the design of this functionality include:

• Use a server-generated filename if storing uploaded files on disk.
  • Inspect the content of uploaded files
column2: and enforce a whitelist of accepted
column4: enforce a blacklist of common executable formats
column5:
to hinder hybrid file attacks.
  • Enforce a whitelist of accepted

column1: <li>If uploaded files are downloaded by users
column2: supply an accurate non-generic Content-Type header
column4: and also a Content-Disposition header that specifies that browsers should handle the file as an attachment.

column1: <li>Enforce a size limit on uploaded files (for defense-in-depth
column2:
this can be implemented both within application code and in the web server's configuration).
  • Reject attempts to upload archive formats such as ZIP.
    • ]]>

Most browsers have a facility to remember user credentials that are entered into HTML forms. This function can be configured by the user and also by applications that employ user credentials. If the function is enabled
column2: then credentials entered by the user are stored on their local computer and retrieved by the browser on future visits to the same application.

column1: The stored credentials can be captured by an attacker who gains control over the user's computer. Further
column2:
an attacker who finds a separate application vulnerability such as cross-site scripting may be able to exploit this to retrieve a user's browser-stored credentials.

]]>

column1: To prevent browsers from storing credentials entered into HTML forms
column2: include the attribute autocomplete="off" within the FORM tag (to protect all form fields) or within the relevant INPUT tags (to protect specific individual fields).

column1:
Please note that modern web browsers may ignore this directive. In spite of this there is a chance that not disabling autocomplete may cause problems obtaining PCI compliance.

]]>

If a page fails to set an appropriate X-Frame-Options or Content-Security-Policy HTTP header
column2: it might be possible for a page controlled by an attacker to load it within an iframe. This may enable a clickjacking attack
column3: in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes
column4: the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery
column5: and may result in unauthorized actions.

column1: Note that some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself
column3: this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.

column1:
You should determine whether any functions accessible within frameable pages can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application.

]]>

column2: the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether
column3:
or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself. Note that the SAMEORIGIN header can be partially bypassed if the application itself can be made to frame untrusted websites.

]]>
